deliberation: I checked the command to put a shofar to the mouth and the mention of covenant and Torah. These are literal cultic/legal terms. The clearly figurative element is the comparison to an eagle over the House of YHWH, an explicit simile for the imminent enemy attack/judgment.

instances.english_text: Like an eagle over the House of GOD
target: the impending enemy attack on Israel/its sanctuary
foreign invasion as an instrument of divine judgment
historical-political judgment on the covenant people
vehicle: an eagle hovering over its prey or nest
a bird of prey poised to swoop and strike
ground: the sudden, swift, menacing overshadowing of a vulnerable victim
speed, inevitability, and terror of the coming attack
danger and overpowering force
posture: a warning about looming destructive judgment
instances.explanation: The enemy/judgment is likened to an eagle hovering over its prey, highlighting the speed and inevitability of the coming attack on YHWH’s ‘house’ (temple/people).

deliberation: I looked for metaphors or similes in the cry itself but the figurative force lies in the contrast between what Israel says and what is actually true in the context of Hosea. Their confession 'My God, we know you' is quoted ironically, since the surrounding verses show they do not truly know YHWH.

instances.english_text: "O my God, we are devoted to You / we know You, Israel"
target: Israel’s actual covenant knowledge and loyalty
their spiritual and moral condition
their religious relationship to YHWH
vehicle: Israel’s spoken claim 'My God, we know you'
a verbal confession of intimacy and devotion
ground: the discrepancy between their claim and their behavior
hypocrisy or self-deception exposed by context
a clash between words and reality
instances.explanation: The prophet quotes Israel’s declaration ironically. They claim to know God, but the surrounding accusations show this is precisely what they lack; the irony functions as a figurative device exposing hypocrisy.

deliberation: The verse is very brief: Israel has 'rejected the good' and an enemy will pursue him. The pursuit language is straightforward military imagery. The debated expression is 'the good' (הטוב), which in context functions as a metonymic summary for YHWH and His covenantal way, rather than just an abstract moral quality.

target: YHWH Himself and His covenantal ways/commands
divine goodness embodied in Torah and true worship
the covenant relationship with God
vehicle: "the good" as a single abstract object
a summary label standing for God’s will and presence
ground: God and His ways are characterized as the good par excellence
to abandon God’s covenant is to abandon 'the good'
ethical valuation of covenant faithfulness
posture: a negative evaluative stance on their choice
instances.explanation: ‘The good’ functions metonymically for YHWH’s own covenantal way (and arguably for YHWH Himself as 'the Good One'). It is not just any generic goodness but shorthand for the whole divinely willed order Israel has spurned.

deliberation: I examined the language of making kings and princes, and of fashioning idols from silver and gold. These descriptions align with literal political and cultic actions. There is strong theological evaluation but no overt metaphor, simile, or other clear figure beyond normal prophetic diction.

I considered the rejection of the calf of Samaria, the burning of YHWH’s anger, and the question about their ability to be pure. The 'calf' stands for the whole idolatrous cult (metonymy/synecdoche), and 'my anger burns' is a conventional Hebrew idiom/metaphor for intense wrath. These are distinct figurative units.

target: Samaria’s entire calf-centered idolatrous religious system
the illicit cult of the northern kingdom
Israel’s corrupt worship practices
vehicle: the cult image at the center of worship
ground: the calf image is representative of the whole cultic system
centrality of that idol to Samaria’s religion
using a part/central symbol to stand for the whole
posture: sharp condemnation of the cult symbol and all it represents
instances.explanation: The 'calf' is more than a literal statue; it stands metonymically for the entire idolatrous system of Samaria which YHWH rejects.

target: YHWH’s intense wrath toward Israel’s idolatry
divine emotional response to their sin
the sphere of theological judgment
vehicle: a burning nose/face (Hebrew idiom for anger as heat)
ground: both anger and fire are experienced as hot and intense
idea of emotion flaring up and consuming like fire
visceral, forceful, potentially destructive power
instances.explanation: The idiom 'my nose burns' portrays God’s wrath as a kind of inner fire, a conventional metaphor in biblical Hebrew for intense anger.

deliberation: The first clauses stress the human manufacture and non-divinity of the calf—largely literal critique. The statement that the calf of Samaria will 'become splinters' is figurative, vividly portraying its total destruction and worthlessness.

instances.english_text: For the calf of Samaria shall become splinters
target: the idol of Samaria and its idolatrous system
false worship under judgment
the religious-political power structure tied to the calf
ground: from seemingly solid and impressive to shattered and useless
complete loss of strength, stability, and value
humiliating, irreparable destruction
posture: mocking prediction of the idol’s downfall
contempt for its impotence before God
prophetic threat of total judgment on idolatry
instances.explanation: The calf is said to 'become splinters,' a metaphor for its being utterly shattered and rendered worthless, emphasizing the fragility and futility of the idol.

deliberation: The entire verse is an extended agricultural image: sowing wind, reaping whirlwind, barren stalks, no flour, and strangers devouring whatever might be produced. These elements cohere into a single sustained metaphor for the self-destructive futility of Israel’s conduct and its disastrous consequences, so I treat them as one complex figurative instance rather than multiple separate ones.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי רוּחַ יִזְרָעוּ וְסוּפָתָה יִקְצֹרוּ קָמָה אֵין־לוֹ צֶמַח בְּלִי יַעֲשֶׂה־קֶּמַח אוּלַי יַעֲשֶׂה זָרִים יִבְלָעֻהוּ
instances.english_text: They sow wind, and they shall reap whirlwind—standing stalks devoid of ears and yielding no flour. If they do yield any, strangers shall devour it.
target: Israel’s futile and sinful policies (idolatry, alliances) and their outcomes
human actions and their consequences under God’s moral order
covenant behavior and ensuing judgment
vehicle: sowing wind, reaping whirlwind, barren stalks, lost harvest eaten by others
natural/agricultural imagery of crop failure and loss
ground: empty or misguided actions produce amplified disaster, not blessing
law of sowing and reaping: what you plant (emptiness) comes back in destructive form (whirlwind)
futility, lack of yield, and loss of results to outsiders
posture: grim, proverbial tone reinforcing divine justice
instances.explanation: Israel’s vain schemes are portrayed as sowing wind; the result is a whirlwind of judgment and a barren or confiscated harvest, a hyperbolic agricultural metaphor for moral futility and catastrophic consequences.

deliberation: I noted two separate figurative moves: (1) Israel is 'swallowed up', using devouring imagery for national collapse, and (2) they have become among the nations 'like an unwanted vessel', an explicit simile for their rejected status. These are distinct figures, not just parts of one image.

target: Israel’s political and social collapse among the nations
national destruction and loss of independence
the historical fate of the northern kingdom
vehicle: an organism or object consumed by a larger one
ground: total overpowering and absorption by a stronger force
disappearance as a distinct entity
helplessness of the devoured before the devourer
instances.explanation: National destruction is portrayed as being 'swallowed up', a metaphor of devouring that underscores Israel’s complete loss of autonomy and identity among the nations.

target: Israel’s standing and desirability among the nations
their perceived value and honor
their international/social status
vehicle: an object no one values or uses
ground: rejected, of no practical worth, set aside
no one finds it desirable or necessary
shame, disposability, and lack of honor
posture: a contemptuous assessment of Israel’s condition
prophetic scorn at their reduced status
instances.explanation: Israel is compared to a vessel that nobody wants, a simile emphasizing their rejection and worthlessness in the eyes of the surrounding nations.

deliberation: Two distinct figures appear: (1) Ephraim is likened, in verbless metaphor, to a solitary wild donkey, portraying stubborn, reckless behavior; (2) Ephraim 'hires lovers', continuing Hosea’s marriage/adultery metaphor where political alliances are cast as illicit sexual liaisons.

instances.english_text: Ephraim is a lonely wild ass
target: Ephraim/Israel’s self-willed, reckless approach to foreign powers
their national character and behavior
their political-spiritual stance
vehicle: an untamed, stubborn animal roaming alone
ground: stubborn independence and refusal of guidance
wandering after one’s own impulses without restraint
vulnerability created by solitary, unrestrained roaming
instances.explanation: Ephraim is metaphorically called a 'wild ass alone', highlighting their stubborn, unrestrained pursuit of their own way, especially in foreign policy.

target: Ephraim’s payment of tribute to secure foreign alliances (especially Assyria)
their political dependence and diplomacy
international relations as acts of covenant infidelity
vehicle: a woman hiring or paying lovers for sexual relations
ground: seeking intimacy and help outside the legitimate covenant partner
shameful, paid dependence rather than faithful love
betrayal, impurity, and reversal of proper roles
posture: moral condemnation framed through marital unfaithfulness
instances.explanation: Political alliances bought with tribute are depicted as an adulterous woman hiring lovers, a central Hoseanic metaphor for Israel’s unfaithfulness to YHWH.

deliberation: I considered whether the 'courting among the nations' continues the lover metaphor; the syntax is debated, but the clearest figurative element in the verse is the 'burden of king and princes', where oppressive rule is portrayed as a heavy load. That is a distinct, conventional metaphor.

instances.english_text: from the burden of king and officers

political oppression and exploitation
socio-political conditions resulting from their alliances
vehicle: a physical burden or load that one must carry
a heavy weight pressing down on a bearer
ground: both physical loads and oppressive rule cause strain and exhaustion
experience of being weighed down and diminished by another’s demands
sense of heaviness, pressure, and depletion
posture: warning about the costly consequences of their choices
prophetic lament/judgment on their self-inflicted oppression
instances.explanation: The demands of kings and princes are described as a 'burden', using load-bearing imagery to portray the heaviness and exhaustion of political oppression.

deliberation: The verse plays on 'altars for sin'—intended for dealing with guilt—becoming 'altars for sinning'. The same phrase is used with opposite functions, creating rhetorical irony: the more altars they build, the more they sin. This is not a metaphor but a sharp ironic reversal.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־הִרְבָּה אֶפְרַיִם מִזְבְּחוֹת לַחֲטֹא הָיוּ־לוֹ מִזְבְּחוֹת לַחֲטֹא
instances.english_text: For Ephraim has multiplied altars for sin; they have become for him altars for sinning.
target: Ephraim’s sacrificial system meant to address guilt
their religious institutions and rituals
their approach to dealing with sin
vehicle: altars whose intended purpose (atonement) is inverted to produce more sin
ground: what was meant as remedy becomes part of the disease
perversion of purpose and function
self-contradictory outcomes of misguided piety
posture: mocking exposure of the corruption of worship
instances.explanation: By repeating 'altars for sin' with opposite functional implications, the prophet uses irony: altars intended to deal with sin actually become places where sin multiplies.

deliberation: YHWH’s many teachings are said to be 'considered like something foreign' (כמו זר). This is an explicit simile: Torah is likened to a foreign object/person to stress Israel’s estrangement from what should be familiar.

instances.english_text: They have been treated as something foreign
target: YHWH’s many teachings/instructions given to Israel
Torah content and divine revelation
the covenantal word of God
vehicle: an alien entity not belonging to the household
ground: what is 'foreign' is not recognized as one’s own and is kept at a distance
lack of acceptance, familiarity, and loyalty
estrangement and suspicion toward what should be embraced
posture: lamenting and rebuking Israel’s rejection of Torah
instances.explanation: Torah is likened to a foreign thing, a simile that underscores how Israel treats God’s own teachings as if they were alien and unwelcome.

deliberation: The verse describes sacrifice and God’s non-acceptance in largely literal cultic terms. The phrase 'they shall return to Egypt' is more than geography in Hosea; Egypt functions as a symbol/metonym for renewed slavery/exile, evoking a metaphorical 'back to bondage' movement.

instances.english_text: Back to Egypt with them! / They shall return to Egypt.
target: Israel’s impending exile and renewed bondage under foreign powers (especially Assyria)
national judgment and loss of freedom
the undoing of the Exodus salvation
vehicle: a literal return to the land of Egypt
re-enslavement in the place of former bondage
ground: returning to Egypt evokes going back into slavery and foreign domination
reversal of redemption and restoration of a prior oppressed state
bondage, humiliation, and alien rule
posture: prophetic warning that prior salvation can be reversed by disobedience
instances.explanation: ‘Return to Egypt’ functions as a metaphoric/metonymic way of saying Israel will go back into a state of bondage and exile, undoing the freedom granted in the Exodus.

deliberation: Forgetting the Maker and building palaces/cities is stated literally. The figurative element is the description of fire 'eating' or 'consuming' the fortresses: fire is personified as a devourer, a common biblical image for devastating judgment.
